0.name: Background
structure: Represents non-labeled or non-specific tissue in neuroimaging
Includes regions not assigned to a specific cerebellar structure
Typically used as a reference or null label in segmentation and visualization
function: No specific neurological function
Serves as a placeholder in imaging datasets to differentiate labeled structures from surrounding tissue
Ensures accurate visualization by providing contrast to labeled cerebellar regions

1.name: Left-I-IV
structure: Anterior lobe lobules I-IV in the left cerebellar hemisphere
Located in the most rostral portion of the cerebellum, adjacent to the primary fissure
Receives input primarily from the spinocerebellar tracts
Projects to the fastigial nucleus of the deep cerebellar nuclei
function: Processes proprioceptive information from the ipsilateral lower limbs
Involved in the coordination of posture and gross motor movements
Contributes to maintenance of balance and equilibrium during stance and locomotion
Damage may result in ataxic gait and impaired lower limb coordination

2.name: Right-I-IV
structure: Anterior lobe lobules I-IV in the right cerebellar hemisphere
Positioned in the superior and anterior aspect of the cerebellum
Connected to the spinal cord via spinocerebellar pathways
Contains significant representation of lower limb somatotopy
function: Processes proprioceptive information from the ipsilateral lower limbs
Contributes to automated postural adjustments during standing and walking
Modulates muscle tone and coordination of leg movements
Works with vestibular system to maintain postural stability

3.name: Left-V
structure: Lobule V of the left cerebellar hemisphere within the anterior lobe
Located immediately anterior to the primary fissure
Receives input from spinocerebellar tracts and corticopontocerebellar pathways
Contains representations of the ipsilateral upper and lower limbs
function: Coordinates voluntary movements of the ipsilateral limbs
Involved in the timing and execution of skilled motor sequences
Participates in the learning of procedural motor skills
Contributes to motor planning and execution of limb movements

4.name: Right-V
structure: Lobule V of the right cerebellar hemisphere within the anterior lobe
Positioned just rostral to the primary fissure
Receives substantial somatosensory input via spinocerebellar tracts
Contains somatotopic representations with emphasis on limb coordination
function: Mediates coordination of voluntary ipsilateral limb movements
Contributes to motor learning and adaptation of movement patterns
Processes proprioceptive feedback during ongoing movements
Involved in error correction during execution of skilled movements

5.name: Left-VI
structure: Lobule VI of the left cerebellar hemisphere in the posterior lobe
Located posterior to the primary fissure
Receives extensive input from corticopontocerebellar pathways
Contains representations of hand and orofacial regions
function: Involved in coordination of fine motor movements, particularly of the hands
Participates in cognitive aspects of motor planning and execution
Contributes to procedural learning and motor adaptation
Active during language-related motor tasks and articulation

6.name: Vermis-VI
structure: Midline vermis portion of lobule VI, connecting left and right hemispheres
Part of the posterior lobe of the cerebellum
Receives vestibular, visual, and auditory inputs
Projects primarily to the fastigial nucleus
function: Coordinates eye movements and gaze stabilization
Involved in midline motor control and postural adjustments of the trunk
Participates in emotional processing via connections with limbic structures
Contributes to spatial orientation and visual guidance of movement

7.name: Right-VI
structure: Lobule VI of the right cerebellar hemisphere in the posterior lobe
Positioned immediately posterior to the primary fissure
Receives substantial input from prefrontal and premotor cortical areas
Contains representation of hand, fingers, and orofacial regions
function: Facilitates coordination of fine motor skills and manual dexterity
Involved in the cognitive aspects of motor control and planning
Contributes to motor learning and adaptation
Participates in language-related motor functions

8.name: Left-Crus-I
structure: Crus I of the left cerebellar hemisphere, part of lobule VII
Located in the lateral posterior lobe, superior to Crus II
Receives extensive projections from prefrontal and parietal cortices
Forms part of the cerebellar cognitive-affective circuit
function: Involved in higher cognitive functions including working memory and executive functions
Participates in language processing, particularly verbal fluency
Contributes to visuospatial processing and attention
Engaged during complex problem-solving tasks

9.name: Vermis-Crus-I
structure: Midline vermis portion corresponding to Crus I
Situated in the posterior aspect of the cerebellar vermis
Receives input from limbic and association cortices
Projects to fastigial nucleus and vestibular nuclei
function: Involved in emotional processing and affective regulation
Contributes to spatial navigation and orientation
Participates in multisensory integration
Mediates aspects of social cognition and emotional learning

10.name: Right-Crus-I
structure: Crus I of the right cerebellar hemisphere, part of lobule VII
Located in the lateral posterior cerebellar lobe
Receives projections from association cortices and default mode network
Contains non-motor representations with cognitive specialization
function: Supports executive functions including working memory and cognitive flexibility
Involved in language processing, particularly semantic aspects
Contributes to attention shifting and task-switching
Participates in social cognition and theory of mind

11.name: Left-Crus-II
structure: Crus II of the left cerebellar hemisphere, part of lobule VII
Located inferior to Crus I in the lateral posterior lobe
Receives input from prefrontal, temporal, and parietal association areas
Forms part of the cerebellar cognitive network
function: Involved in abstract reasoning and higher-order cognitive processing
Participates in language comprehension and semantic processing
Contributes to emotional regulation and social cognition
Engaged during complex problem-solving and planning tasks

12.name: Vermis-Crus-II
structure: Midline vermis component corresponding to Crus II
Connected to limbic structures including hypothalamus and amygdala
Receives input from emotional processing networks
Projects to fastigial nucleus and other deep cerebellar nuclei
function: Mediates emotional responses and affective regulation
Involved in autonomic control related to emotional states
Contributes to fear conditioning and emotional learning
Participates in stress responses and emotional homeostasis

13.name: Right-Crus-II
structure: Crus II of the right cerebellar hemisphere, part of lobule VII
Situated in the inferolateral aspect of the posterior lobe
Receives extensive input from multimodal association cortices
Contains primarily non-motor representations
function: Supports executive functions and cognitive control processes
Involved in language processing, particularly narrative comprehension
Contributes to social cognition and emotional processing
Participates in higher-order attention and working memory tasks

14.name: Left-VIIb
structure: Lobule VIIb of the left cerebellar hemisphere
Located posterior to Crus II in the posterior lobe
Receives input from association cortices and pontine nuclei
Contains both motor and cognitive representations
function: Involved in complex motor sequence planning and execution
Contributes to cognitive aspects of motor control
Participates in procedural learning and skill acquisition
Mediates coordination between cognitive processing and motor output

15.name: Vermis-VIIb
structure: Midline vermis portion of lobule VIIb
Connected to vestibular nuclei and brainstem centers
Receives input from vestibular and proprioceptive pathways
Projects primarily to fastigial nucleus
function: Contributes to balance and postural control during complex movements
Involved in oculomotor control and gaze stabilization
Participates in the coordination of head and trunk movements
Mediates vestibular processing for spatial orientation

16.name: Right-VIIb
structure: Lobule VIIb of the right cerebellar hemisphere
Positioned in the posterior lobe between Crus II and VIIIa
Receives input from motor, premotor, and association cortices
Contains mixed motor and cognitive representations
function: Coordinates complex motor sequences and skilled movements
Participates in motor planning and sensorimotor integration
Contributes to procedural learning and motor adaptation
Involved in the cognitive control of movement

17.name: Left-VIIIa
structure: Anterior subdivision of lobule VIII in the left cerebellar hemisphere
Located in the posterior-inferior region of the cerebellum
Receives input primarily from motor cortex and spinocerebellar tracts
Contains representation of lower limbs and trunk
function: Involved in coordination of lower limb movements
Contributes to automated aspects of gait and locomotion
Participates in postural adjustments during walking
Mediates sensorimotor integration for leg movements

18.name: Vermis-VIIIa
structure: Midline vermis portion of lobule VIIIa
Connected to vestibular and reticular nuclei
Receives input from vestibular afferents and proprioceptive pathways
Projects to fastigial and vestibular nuclei
function: Maintains midline postural control and balance
Coordinates trunk and proximal limb movements
Contributes to vestibular processing and spatial orientation
Involved in automated aspects of upright posture

19.name: Right-VIIIa
structure: Anterior subdivision of lobule VIII in the right cerebellar hemisphere
Located in the posterior-inferior cerebellar region
Receives substantial input from motor cortex and spinal afferents
Contains representation of ipsilateral lower limbs
function: Coordinates lower extremity movements and locomotion
Contributes to automated motor patterns during walking
Mediates sensorimotor integration for leg coordination
Involved in the timing and rhythm of repetitive leg movements

20.name: Left-VIIIb
structure: Posterior subdivision of lobule VIII in the left cerebellar hemisphere
Located in the inferomedial region of the posterior lobe
Receives input from motor cortex and spinocerebellar pathways
Contains representation of lower limbs with emphasis on distal control
function: Mediates fine control of foot and ankle movements
Contributes to precision aspects of lower limb coordination
Involved in the adaptation of gait to changing terrain
Participates in error correction during locomotion

21.name: Vermis-VIIIb
structure: Midline vermis portion of lobule VIIIb
Connected to vestibular and reticular formation circuits
Receives input from vestibular and proprioceptive systems
Projects primarily to fastigial nucleus
function: Coordinates axial and proximal muscle activation patterns
Contributes to postural adjustments during complex movements
Involved in the vestibular control of balance
Mediates automatic postural responses to perturbations

22.name: Right-VIIIb
structure: Posterior subdivision of lobule VIII in the right cerebellar hemisphere
Located in the posterior-inferior aspect of the cerebellum
Receives input from motor cortex and spinocerebellar tracts
Contains somatotopic representation of distal lower limb structures
function: Coordinates fine motor control of foot and ankle movements
Involved in the precision aspects of lower limb coordination
Contributes to adaptation of gait patterns
Participates in the learning of skilled foot movements

23.name: Left-IX
structure: Lobule IX (uvula) of the left cerebellar hemisphere
Located in the posterior-inferior region of the cerebellum
Receives vestibular and autonomic inputs
Connected to vestibulocerebellum circuits
function: Processes vestibular information for balance and spatial orientation
Involved in autonomic control related to motion perception
Contributes to the control of eye movements and visual tracking
Participates in cardiovascular and respiratory autonomic regulation

24.name: Vermis-IX
structure: Midline vermis portion of lobule IX (uvula)
Significant component of the vestibulocerebellum
Receives primary vestibular afferents and visual inputs
Projects to fastigial nucleus and vestibular nuclei
function: Central role in balance and equilibrium maintenance
Coordinates eye movements in response to head motion
Involved in processing of gravitational and linear acceleration
Contributes to spatial orientation and motion perception

25.name: Right-IX
structure: Lobule IX (uvula) of the right cerebellar hemisphere
Located in the posterior-inferior cerebellar region
Receives substantial vestibular and autonomic inputs
Part of the vestibulocerebellum functional system
function: Processes vestibular signals for balance and spatial orientation
Involved in oculomotor control and gaze stabilization
Contributes to autonomic responses related to motion and balance
Participates in the integration of visual and vestibular information

26.name: Left-X
structure: Lobule X (flocculus) of the left cerebellar hemisphere
Most inferior portion of the cerebellum
Receives direct vestibular afferents and visual motion inputs
Key component of the vestibulocerebellum
function: Critical for vestibulo-ocular reflex adaptation
Mediates smooth pursuit eye movements and gaze stabilization
Essential for maintaining visual fixation during head movement
Involved in motion sickness and spatial disorientation responses

27.name: Vermis-X
structure: Midline vermis portion of lobule X (nodulus)
Most inferior aspect of the cerebellar vermis
Receives direct vestibular input from semicircular canals and otolith organs
Projects to vestibular nuclei and fastigial nucleus
function: Processes otolithic gravitational signals
Essential for spatial orientation with respect to gravity
Integrates vestibular and proprioceptive information for balance
Involved in autonomic responses to changes in position and motion

28.name: Right-X
structure: Lobule X (flocculus) of the right cerebellar hemisphere
Located at the most inferolateral aspect of the cerebellum
Receives direct vestibular and visual motion inputs
Forms a key component of the vestibulocerebellum
function: Mediates adaptation of the vestibulo-ocular reflex
Controls smooth pursuit eye movements and gaze stability
Essential for maintaining visual fixation during head movement
Processes visual-vestibular mismatch signals during motion
